title: Lesson 50 – Have and Got; Magka-, Magkaroon and Maging

vocabulary.english: verb prefix that means “to come to have”

contents.markdown: In previous lessons you have seen several ways to say “have” or “got” in Tagalog. In this lesson we will summarize them and give you some new ones.
<u>Ways to say “Have” or “Got” that you have Seen </u>

item.english: I got/took a car. (Just reporting a fact.)

contents.markdown: **Um- verbs with the nuance “to become adjective”**

item.english: I got/became big. (There was a process involved.)
I have a car. (Just reporting a fact.)
I have a car. (Just reporting a fact.)

contents.markdown: _Magka_- is a verb prefix that can have several traits, one of which is to add the nuance “come to have” or “acquire”. These are AF verbs whose aspects are formed similar to _maka_- verbs.

Notice that the stress stays on the same vowel in the root as in the infinitive, and in the uncompleted and contemplated aspects the first _ka_ is always stressed. _Magka_- indicates that there was a process involved:

item.english: Maybe they will end up having a child.
Have you ever had a spouse?

contents.markdown: You can probably imagine a process in having a child or spouse, but how about:

item.english: She would like to have a cat.

contents.markdown: This implies that she would like to go through the process of acquiring a cat, or perhaps own one for a long time. Compare to just:

item.english: She would like to get a cat.

contents.markdown: The process is not emphasized with _kumuha_.
_Magkaroon_ is just a specific _magka_- verb which means to “come to have” or “acquire”. The root is _mayroon_, from which only _roon_ is used to form the verb.

item.english: Maybe they will end up having a child.

item.tagalog: Nagkaroon ka na ba ng asawa?
item.english: Have you ever had a spouse?
She would like to have a cat.

contents.markdown: One way to say “to become noun/adjective” is to use _maging_. _Maging_ is a unique AF verb; it is not a _ma_- verb because it uses different grammar and stress patterns.
Notice that although it conjugates like a _ma_- verb, its uncompleted and contemplated stress patterns are different.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sino ang masaya sa sarili niya kasi may bahay pa siya?
exampleSentences.english: Who is happy with herself because she still has a house?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Baka nakakainis si Luis, kasi hindi pa siya nagkaanak.
exampleSentences.english: Maybe Luis is annoying because he has not had a child yet. (magka-)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi ko alam kung aling lugar ang magkakaroon ng tubig.
exampleSentences.english: I do not know which place is the one that will have water. (magkaroon)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nagiging nakakatakot po ba ang lugar kung saan ka nakatira?
exampleSentences.english: Is the place where you are living getting scary? (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Naaalala mo ba ang lalaking nagkatrabaho sa kanila?
exampleSentences.english: Do you remember the man who had a job at their place? (magka-)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Gagawin ni Angel ang bahay, kasi gusto niyang magkaroon ng aso.
exampleSentences.english: Angel will build the house because she wants to have a dog. (magkaroon)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailangan nating makapagluto, kaya nakasapatos tayo.
exampleSentences.english: We (incl.) need to be able to cook, so we are wearing shoes.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakabili si Joe ng sasakyan, kasi nagkapera siya, di ba?
exampleSentences.english: Joe was able to buy a car because he acquired money, right? (magka-)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Naiisip ko ang maraming bagay na nakakatuwang magkaroon.
exampleSentences.english: I am able to think of the many things that would be fun to have. (magkaroon)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Magiging pangulo si Sir Santos, kasi meron siyang magandang kasama.
exampleSentences.english: Mr. Santos will become president because he has a beautiful companion. (meron)
